prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe the dust continuum emission of the target, obtaining the best possible spatial resolution to properly separate the AGN emission from that of the host galaxy and probe the higher-excitation gas likely to be found in the most active star-forming regions of the host, and near to the AGN. The LO will be positioned to sample the frequencies of the CO(7-6) and the CI transitions that will provide more detailed information on the properties of the gas, and to possibly detect high-velocity molecular gas, flowing out from the vicinity of the AGN.
The required sensitivity coupled with the spatial resolution will provide a very powerful constraint on the relative strength of host and AGN emission.
- Sensitivity: The expected continuum flux density at the representative frequency has been derived from our SED modelling: as detailed in the science justification, the multiwavelength coverage below ~10 micron allowed us to disentangle the AGN/host galaxy contribution at the observed wavelengths, and therefore provided us with a solid estimate of the AGN emission also in the ALMA bands; however, no constraints can be obtained for the type and star-forming properties of the host galaxy, expected to be observed in the ALMA band (taking into account the source redshift, z~2). Here we conservatively adopted the lowest contribution obtained in our SED modelling, obtained considering a typical late-type spiral template instead of the observed SED of particular sources (e.g., starburst galaxies or ULIRG). On the basis of previous K-band observations, the source is expected to be extended, but with angular dimension lower than the LRS expected in the most extended 12m configuration. The requested angular resolution, corresponding to ~1.5 kpc at the source redshift, is fundamental to investigate the continuum properties both near the actively accreting nucleus and in the most external regions, where we expect to observe the only host emission. Since the minimum on-source exposure time is set to 2 min, the estimated SNR on the continuum will be ~25; based on our estimates, this will provide a detection of the main emission lines falling in the observed frequency range (from a 4 sigma detection down to a 2 sigma upper limit, depending on the source star-forming properties, that will be determined by the proposed continuum observations).
- Imaging: With the proposed observational set-up, we do not intend to reconstruct a detailed description of the source components. Therefore, the uv-coverage offered for Cycle 2, although coarser as compared with the full array, will be able to produce the desired map of the source.
- Correlator setup: The sky frequency has been moved in a position that (i) allows us to sample the redshifted CO(7-6) (observed at 270.1GHz) and CI lines (observed at 270.9 GHz), and (ii) guarantee an optimal transmissive position for both the sidebands.
- Calibration: No user-defined calibration is required.
- Scheduling/time constraints: No time constraints are required.

We propose to observe the dust continuum emission of the target, obtaining the best possible spatial resolution to properly separate the AGN emission from that of the host galaxy and probe the higher-excitation gas likely to be found in the most active star-forming regions of the host, and near to the AGN. The LO will be positioned to sample the frequency of the CII transition that will provide more detailed information on the properties of the gas, and to possibly detect high-velocity molecular gas, flowing out from the vicinity of the AGN.
The required sensitivity coupled with the spatial resolution will provide a very powerful constraint on the relative strength of host and AGN emission.
- Sensitivity: The expected continuum flux density at the representative frequency has been derived from our SED modelling: as detailed in the science justification, the multiwavelength coverage below ~10 micron allowed us to disentangle the AGN/host galaxy contribution at the observed wavelengths, and therefore provided us with a solid estimate of the AGN emission also in the ALMA bands; however, no constraints can be obtained for the type and star-forming properties of the host galaxy, expected to be observed in the ALMA band (taking into account the source redshift, z~2). Here we conservatively adopted the lowest contribution obtained in our SED modelling, obtained considering a typical late-type spiral template instead of the observed SED of particular sources (e.g., starburst galaxies or ULIRG). On the basis of previous K-band observations, the source is expected to be extended, but with angular dimension lower than the LRS expected in the most compact 12m configuration. The requested angular resolution, corresponding to ~1.5 kpc at the source redshift, is fundamental to investigate the continuum properties both near the actively accreting nucleus and in the most external regions, where we expect to observe the only host emission. The estimated SNR on the continuum will allow us to detect an emission in excess with respect to the AGN continuum at more than 2sigma also for a host with a low-level of SFR. Moreover, based on our estimates, for typical line parameters this SNR will provide a detection with at least 3sigma confidence level of the main emission line falling in the observed frequency range.
- Imaging: With the proposed observational set-up, we do not intend to reconstruct a detailed description of the source components. Therefore, the uv-coverage offered for Cycle 2, although coarser as compared with the full array, will be able to produce the desired map of the source.
- Correlator setup: The sky frequency has been moved in a position that (i) allows us to sample the redshifted CII line (observed at 636.3 GHz), and (ii) guarantee an optimal transmissive position for both the sidebands.
- Calibration: No user-defined calibration is required.
- Scheduling/time constraints: No time constraints are required.

We propose to observe the dust continuum emission of the target, obtaining the best possible spatial resolution to properly separate the AGN emission from that of the host galaxy and probe the higher-excitation gas likely to be found in the most active star-forming regions of the host, and near to the AGN. The LO will be positioned to sample the frequency of the CO(12-11) transition that will provide more detailed information on the properties of the gas, and to possibly detect high-velocity molecular gas, flowing out from the vicinity of the AGN.
The required sensitivity coupled with the spatial resolution will provide a very powerful constraint on the relative strength of host and AGN emission.
- Sensitivity: The expected continuum flux density at the representative frequency has been derived from our SED modelling: as detailed in the science justification, the multiwavelength coverage below ~10 micron allowed us to disentangle the AGN/host galaxy contribution at the observed wavelengths, and therefore provided us with a solid estimate of the AGN emission also in the ALMA bands; however, no constraints can be obtained for the type and star-forming properties of the host galaxy, expected to be observed in the ALMA band (taking into account the source redshift, z~2). Here we conservatively adopted the lowest contribution obtained in our SED modelling, obtained considering a typical late-type spiral template instead of the observed SED of particular sources (e.g., starburst galaxies or ULIRG). On the basis of previous K-band observations, the source is expected to be extended, but with angular dimension well below than the LRS expected in the most compact 12m configuration. The requested angular resolution, corresponding to ~1.5 kpc at the source redshift, is fundamental to investigate the continuum properties both near the actively accreting nucleus and in the most external regions, where we expect to observe the only host emission. The estimated SNR on the continuum will allow us to detect an emission in excess with respect to the AGN continuum at more than 1sigma also for a host with a low-level of SFR.
- Imaging: With the proposed observational set-up, we do not intend to reconstruct a detailed description of the source components. Therefore, the uv-coverage offered for Cycle 2, although coarser as compared with the full array, will be able to produce the desired map of the source.
- Correlator setup: The sky frequency has been moved in a position that (i) allows us to sample the redshifted CO(12-11) line (observed at 462.7 GHz), and (ii) guarantee an optimal transmissive position for both the sidebands.
- Calibration: No user-defined calibration is required.
- Scheduling/time constraints: No time constraints are required.

We propose to observe the dust continuum emission of the target, obtaining the best possible spatial resolution to properly separate the AGN emission from that of the host galaxy and probe the higher-excitation gas likely to be found in the most active star-forming regions of the host, and near to the AGN. The LO will be positioned to sample the frequency of the CO(9-8) transition that will provide more detailed information on the properties of the gas, and to possibly detect high-velocity molecular gas, flowing out from the vicinity of the AGN.
The required sensitivity coupled with the spatial resolution will provide a very powerful constraint on the relative strength of host and AGN emission.
- Sensitivity: The expected continuum flux density at the representative frequency has been derived from our SED modelling: as detailed in the science justification, the multiwavelength coverage below ~10 micron allowed us to disentangle the AGN/host galaxy contribution at the observed wavelengths, and therefore provided us with a solid estimate of the AGN emission also in the ALMA bands; however, no constraints can be obtained for the type and star-forming properties of the host galaxy, expected to be observed in the ALMA band (taking into account the source redshift, z~2). Here we conservatively adopted the lowest contribution obtained in our SED modelling, obtained considering a typical late-type spiral template instead of the observed SED of particular sources (e.g., starburst galaxies or ULIRG). On the basis of previous K-band observations, the source is expected to be extended, but with angular dimension below than the LRS expected in the most extended 12m configuration. The requested angular resolution, corresponding to ~1.5 kpc at the source redshift, is fundamental to investigate the continuum properties both near the actively accreting nucleus and in the most external regions, where we expect to observe the only host emission. Since the minimum on-source exposure time is set to 2 min, the estimated SNR on the continuum will be ~30; this will allow us to detect an emission in excess with respect to the AGN continuum at more than 6sigma also for a host with a low-level of SFR.
- Imaging: With the proposed observational set-up, we do not intend to reconstruct a detailed description of the source components. Therefore, the uv-coverage offered for Cycle 2, although coarser as compared with the full array, will be able to produce the desired map of the source.
- Correlator setup: The sky frequency has been moved in a position that (i) allows us to sample the redshifted CO(12-11) line (observed at 462.7 GHz), and (ii) guarantee an optimal transmissive position for both the sidebands.
- Calibration: No user-defined calibration is required.
- Scheduling/time constraints: No time constraints are required.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose continuum observations in four bands of XBSJ021642.3-043553, the highest redshift (z~2) X-ray luminous and obscured quasar found in the XMM-Newton Bright Serendipitous Survey. This is an ideal target for detecting star-formation activity in an active nucleus and its host galaxy at the peak of the quasar accretion rate density. The highest spatial capabilities allowed by ALMA are fundamental to distinguish spatially this activity at such a high redshift. In addition, high-velocity outflows, expected for a quasar so luminous (log Lbol~46.6 erg/s) and accreting at a rate very close to the Eddington limit (Eddington ratio~0.4), will be easily detected by ALMA through a sensitive search for the entrained molecular gas. These observations make excellent use of the early array: indeed, thanks to the brightness of the source and the wide photometric coverage available at lower wavelengths, the proposed scientific goal can be achieved by ALMA before reaching its full operational capability.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Bologna, University of
